work.p: This manuscript includes lines that also appear in a longer manuscript notebook draft of a poem unpublished in Whitman's lifetime, titled "Pictures." The first several lines of the notebook, which include versions of the last two lines of this manuscript, were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster (1881, p. 310).

Whitman's early style of inscription in this draft, along with the line "It is round—it has room for America, north and south," and his use of his own name in the deleted first line, all suggest that Whitman may have inscribed this draft around the same time that he was working on the 1856 "Poem of Salutation" (eventually "Salut au Monde!"), which begins: "O TAKE my hand, Walt Whitman! / Such gliding wonders! Such sights and sounds!" (1856, p. 103). This manuscript also suggests that at one point he may have considered linking what would become "Poem of Salutations" and the formally and thematically similar "Pictures" more directly.

Faintly visible at the bottom of the manuscript through the paper upon which it has been mounted is the phrase "inland and seaboard," which appeared in the poem first published in the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass as number 24 of the "Calamus" cluster. The poem was eventually titled "I Hear It was Charged against Me."

titleStmt.title: America, always Pictorial
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: The last two lines of this manuscript were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster (1881, p. 310). The lines also appeared in an earlier and longer manuscript poem titled "Pictures." Richard Maurice Bucke dates these manuscript lines to around 1880, just before "My Picture-Gallery" was published. But Whitman's early style of inscription in this draft, along with the line "It is round—it has room for America, north and south," and his use of his own name in the deleted first line, all suggest that Whitman may have inscribed this draft around the same time that he was working on the 1856 "Poem of Salutations" (eventually "Salut au Monde!"). This draft also suggests that at one point he may have considered linking what would become "Poem of Salutations" and the formally and thematically similar "Pictures" more directly. Faintly visible at the bottom of the manuscript is the phrase "inland and seaboard," which appeared in the poem first published in 1860 as number 24 of the "Calamus" cluster and eventually titled "I Hear It was Charged against Me." In a transcription of this manuscript that appears in The Complete Writings of Walt Whitman: Leaves of Grass, Vol. 3 (New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons, 1902), the final line reads: "It is round—Behold! it has room for America, north and south, seaboard and inland, persons . . . " (268).

bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
On the back of this leaf are two draft lines of poetry, the second of which bears some similarities to the 1860 poem eventually titled "As If a Phantom Caress'd Me."

del.l:
O Walt Whitman, show us some a
few pictures!

add.l:
America, always pictorial! !——and
you Walt Whitman to name the

lg.l:
Yes, in a little house I keep
suspended many pictures—it
is not a fixed house,

It is round——inside behold Behold,! it has room for
al America, north and south,
inland and seaboard
